post.message: Being from Illinois, this story touches me personally. This is so awesome to read!
@twitter-252244987:disqus video is pretty sweet too. Someone get @praetorian in this conversation so we can congratulate him. :)

Very inspiring post, Noreen, love it. Your vulnerability and humility make it so real, and your passion shines through.

Albert
Noreen! This is so great! We have loved, loved, loved working with you! - Alison
'didn't oo = "overwhelming offer" not so long ago?

Are you in need of a Loan/Funding for a project? Have you been trying to obtain a Loan from any of the Banks or Loan Companies and got Ripped off and they have refused to grant you the Loan? we offer all types of non-recourse Loan and funding at a low Interest Rate of 2% both long term and short term.

The categories of Loan/financial funding offered include but not limited to: Business Loan, Personal Loan, Company Loan, Mortgage Loan, debt consolidation and financial funding for both turnkey and mega projects E.T.C. from a minimum of Euro/US$1Million to Euro/US$5Billion Max.

We also also specialize in lease and sales of Bank Guarantee {BG}, Standby Letter of Credit {SBLC}, Medium Term Notes {MTN} and Confirmable Bank Draft {CBD}, this financial instrument is issue from AAA Rated bank such as HSBC Bank, UBS Zurich, Barclays Bank , Standard Chartered Bank E.T.C.

The financial instrument can be invested into High Yield Investment Trading Program {HYITP) or Private Placement Program (PPP). We are direct to a genuine and reliable Financial Organization, without broker chain or chauffer driven offer.

Kindly get in touch for further details and procedure.

Regards

James Allen

Email: jamesallen308@yahoo.com
Thanks a lot for sharing. You have done a brilliant job.
Awesome blog! This was so much fun, and I never thought I'd be able to enjoy dancing in front of that many people! :) We'll win next year!
:) exactly

This is retarded. Next Jump's commitments are to good press and the bottom line.

Look into B corps and L3Cs, for profit entities that also can still get grants/PRIs---we're well on our way to creating true non-profit/for-profit hybrids, and are slowly but surely starting to solve the problems you describe in your article.

Am I the only one who sees the difference between having a for-profit l3c business whose works truly change the world and have their charitable missions COME FIRST, ABOVE ALL, and a coupon site who donates a relatively teeny bit of time or money to a pet cause every few months? come on...

It's true that L3Cs donate a far greater share of their product to the causes they support, but comparing Next Jump to a non-profit is tricky; the key is to compare to all the massive companies that could easily spare a portion of their strength for non-profit causes and yet choose not to. I think the point here is that if every for profit company on the planet donated a teeny bit of time or money to a pet cause every few months, the impact would be massive. You're right that there is a huge difference between Next Jump and L3Cs, but there's also quite some distance between Next Jump and the average for-profit company.

A post examining the need for increased corporate philanthropy would definitely be interesting. Your point: "if every for profit company on the planet donated a teeny bit of time or money to a pet cause every few months, the impact would be massive." is true.

But that's not the point the author makes in her article---she specifically outlines her case for working at Next Jump vs. a NFP, and why she chose one over the other. She denigrates her NFP experience by saying that these types of charitable initiatives are not effective: "If there was one thing I learned from non profits, is that while they have huge hearts that continue to give, they often fail to make the sustainable changes they work for. " --and then continues by discussing how NFPs NEED for-profit companies to come in and save the day with all their money: "...how can non profits have their desired effect? They need the support of larger companies to care and make sustainable changes." Um, slow your roll, honey. There's just so much BS in that whole paragraph my mind was reeling as I read it. Plenty of NFPs do great work without being completely underwritten by corporate sponsors. Plus, as I mention above, there's new designations like L3Cs that help bridge the gap between "doing good" and "making money".

She also speaks to the altruism of Next Jump, which I find ludicrous. I'd argue that Next Jump needs their charitable partnerships as much as those charities appreciate the extra funds. The relationships foster good PR, and incentivize buying through the platform with the "good feeling" of having tossed a few pennies to those poor inner city school children.

This whole article was problematic and poorly written.
Disgusted.

Yipes- hit a nerve here. This girl is "blooming where she is planted" and learning along the way- these are things to encourage and applaud. I think you hit on a number of good points, but the way you are offering that information is not persuasive- it's aggressive and unkind. If you care about the Non-Profit world and care about conveying your message with power- you ought to try a different angle. Now use of the R-word... that is disgusting. Not cool...just simply not cool.

~eyeroll~ Along with this article, the language police are also retarded. You're feigning indignation to gain credence and it's annoying.

I appreciate the acknowledgement of my points and apologize if I didn't sufficiently sugarcoat them enough. It's just so disappointing to see so all of the time, money and hard work so many have given to NFCs written off by a girl who knows first hand how powerful those organizations can be.

It must be nice that anyone can come online anonymously and just bash someone else. Just sounds like someone bitter with nothing else to do, but trash someone who is actually doing something. BTW, you don't need to spell check or grammar check my response. Find something useful to do with your time!

We want to encourage other for-profit companies to give back as we do, proving by example that profitable companies can help these charities while still growing as private businesses. Non-profit companies accomplish amazing things, but are often lacking the funds and publicity corporations can provide. This is not to say that charities rely on corporations, or that they can't get anything done without sponsorship of this style, but rather that the corporations are capable of contributing and by all means should do
so. It's not dissimilar to motives of The Giving Pledge---to show corporations they can spare the money and time needed to make a major difference in the world without disrupting their private goals, and encourage this behavior.

The post talks about a culture at Next Jump built around giving back; the company believes there is an in-between where profit oriented companies can be more responsible through a non-profit mindset. The author of this post wanted to share her story of her personal move from the non-profit sector to a larger business that still has a connection to the non-profit beliefs that she holds. Although we're happy that a conversation is developing about the meaning of the post, such negative language and personal attacks are unacceptable and do nothing to foster the rational dialogue we want to support. Please keep this in mind in further comments.
Respectfully suggesting someone proofreads these posts. This reads like a first draft.
Yes it has worked for me!
Such a simple yet profound example that demonstrates your "why". Thanks, Charlie.
I'm glad your mom planted those trees Charlie!

I love that Next Jump is tackling the question of work/life balance for parents, especially for moms - but the quality of this post is embarrassing. This is an important topic, coming from the very top of Next Jump, and the team certainly hasn't put their best foot forwards.

Furthermore, you didn't go as far as to offer solutions to the reader; all that's said is that the problem was solved. How? What specific things can others do to replicate your progress on this front?

I thought the same thing when I first read this. Then after pausing, I think she did explain "how they did it". It was the commitment
between them to "make it work". There is no out of the box solution. It
will be different for everyone. What works for one team, just won't
work for another. It's the commitment to one another to figure it out
that makes it work. It's not easy. The path is not clear, but the commitment makes it possible. I want specific steps too, but I don't know that they really exist. Perhaps just believing it's possible is the first step.

She provided part of the solution...we needed to create more leaders. This means, there were tremendous investments in leadership development programs. Most organizations run similar to the army. There is a top down approach in leadership, a plan for almost anything. The stress and responsibility lies with the top. The marines operate differently, they empower and train every marine to be able to read any situation and attack it. Engineers or business people, Next Jump is at the beginning of training "business marines", leaders who are able to attack any situation, for-profit/ non-profit, cultural/revenue, work/home, etc.
We will be the first to admit, this is a very big topic and a very challenging one. We certainly don't have all the answers and expect to make many mistakes...but we are committed to figuring this out.
I love that as leaders you find the time to spend with your family

Where does that leave your other employees that are parents ?
You have the opportunity but do your employees?it seems as thought there is work/ life balance with your leaders, can you say the same for your employees?

First to set context, we have to recognize how difficult this is, helping working parents optimize their lives between work and home...with an ultimate goal of becoming great leaders, great mom/dad and great spouse. We started with leaders because when an organization can distribute responsibility out of the hands of a few into the hands of a deep bench of leadership, everyone can win..both at home and at work. The PROCESS of investing in leadership development programs are leading to an OUTCOME of better leaders, with sound judgment, happier all around and most importantly able to truly take responsibility vs take ownership.
So well written. Just amazing to see all the years of hard work be compiled into an amazing piece with links flowing throughout linking to more articles and videos.

Thank you Brian...the story tells itself when we as an organization are deliberating acting and living this human capital pyramid. I especially loved linking to so many different blog posts by other NxJumpers writing about weight loss, finding their voice, finding a purpose, etc.

My dear dinesh
Recognition reflects seriousness by Management of Next Jump about its employee and respecting their values.I wish to convey my hearty wishes for prosperity and growth of Next Jump
KLNarayanan Mumbai India
Well written and a great share for others considering NxJ or other internships...find a job that helps bring out the optimal self in you

A good effort, but I think Maslow had it right, though success has always been in the eye of the beholder. You've essentially just rebranded the original four needs, and dropped perhaps the most important one. How does changing the labels, a wholly semantic exercise by the way, really make the hierarchy more relevant?
Having worked with foster children I must say that the emotional needs of love and belonging cannot be removed from the pyramid. I've seen what happens when those are missing.

Maslow had it right for 1943. Times have changed significantly since then, especially in how we work. For instance, health (fitness and nutrition) is critical now and was not then. Today: most jobs require little to no physical movement and most meals are very bad for your body (it's much harder to eat healthy than not). As for leaving out the most important one: LOVE..the PROCESS of investing in yourself for the purpose of helping others leads to an OUTCOME of others loving you. Nothing was dropped, it was refined...we're constantly iterating to identify the minimum needs to create the greatest outcomes.
Maybe I'm reading it wrong, but I assumed those were included in security?
I appreciate the inclusion of "purpose". I think this is critical to feeling happy in life. We must feel as if we know, and live out, our purpose.

This is a nice attempt, and may work well for board meetings and corporate motivation. My one comment is about purpose as the top of the pyramid -- yes, purpose is important for all the reasons you've stated. Rick Warren (among others) has made a fortune from this idea. However, purpose is only one small part of the bigger "self-actualization" picture. Self-actualized people not only know their purpose, they know their strengths, their identity, their processes, and their history, among other things. That's not just a good idea for 1943, it's a great idea for 2013 and the rest of the millennium to come.The "whole" self-actualized person Maslow described is about more than just purpose. Metacognition, introspection, and refined understandings of self in relationship to the world are also equally important. Purpose can serve as a good starting point, though.
This is fantastic. I think, especially, because a business environment that's built with purpose at the pinnacle can't help but inject love throughout every level of the pyramid.

Mr. Kim,

I see you as looking through the lens of those who have already won the race; maybe the top 15% or so who comprise the technical and managerial class, academics. Are you telling me that there are not millions in this country for whom food and shelter isn't a given? And jobs; there are millions employed in manufacturing, construction, mining, trucking and on and on. In my experience,most working people aren't sitting around in an office all day. And in 1943 are you telling me that fitness wasn't important? So working on an auto assembly line didn't require moving and reaching and bending all day long?

A lot of the things you are saying are good, but they're luxuries, looked at from the ivory tower. Right now, the biggest issue has to be the millions out of work or working at low-paying jobs with little or no benefits. There is no personal security without jobs. For the common good, full employment at living wages must be a political goal. The means are well known, all it takes is the political will to do so.

ohioprole - agree with your statements and job security is of biggest concern for most today. The point i'm making has validity if you look at it from an overall economic/people shift. Decades ago 80% of people made their living in agriculture. Then it shifted to manufacturing. It is predicted that by 2030 80% of all americans will earn a living in the Information Age. That means sitting at desks, sedentary jobs...therefore why fitness becomes more important. Agri and manufacturing jobs had much higher movement than info jobs. The point being the workplace has shifted and is shifting again.
Your site is horrible. Our company uses your site and I have been waiting for a response to my request for over 3 weeks!!! horrible service.
So with job shop software, you think it should be manager shop software? Does the same thing but with people for managers instead of a random job.
Love this post, so honest, heartfelt, sharing of personal struggle and the triumphs with more to come...great writing

Hi Charlie,
what a motivating article. I really enjoyed it. I 100% agree that It's important to make growth and learning fun. Check out Wheeldo.com to learn about a company that creates social games in minutes. Or, read about 5 factors that contribute to employee disengagement. http://blog.wheeldo.com/5-fact...
